Win Bon
Chungking
December 17, 1941
Peasantinee
Hr. H. M. Bixby
Pan American Airways, Inc.
Chrysler Building
New York, M.Y.,
U.S.A.
Dear Mr. Bixby:
On Monday morning,
I was
he had
a message from Manile instructing him not to take off the
Clipper for Kanila. He said he had also been advised by the
Hongkong Government to take off from longkong as
quickly as possi-
ble.
He did not know the reason for either of these two mess-
ages and asked my opinion.
I told him I could not imagine
what
was back of it but considered Hongkong, in case of
trouble,
more
dangerous than Manila and suggested he
drop his passengers
and
take off.
About five or ten minutes later, he called me again and
informed me
that he had just been advised
that Japan had declared
war on Great Britain and America.
I told him that in that case
we would certainly have trouble and that it would be necessary
to get all the planes out of longkong. I suggested that that even-
who knew the country and the lake to accompany him.
I packed a suitcase as quickly as possible and drove
into Hongkong from Repulse Bay at once.
When I
got to Hungkong,
I found the sir raid alarm was on, although I had
not heard it.
My car was stopped several times by air raid wardens but I insist-
ed on going through and got past them.
When I arrived at the of-
fice, I tried to get Kaltak Airport over the phone but could not.
I then decided to go over to Kaltak as quickly as possible.
went to Star Ferry and found it was not running because of
the
raid.
The regulations during the first day, honday,
apparently
prohibited anything from moving during air raid periods.
I. then
they also refused to go.
I ran into a Police Sargeant,
he bad to go to Kowloon and suggested to him that we
go together,
but he said the boats could not go until after the air raid re-
lease had sounded.
I suggested that he use his authority to make
cnego.
He said this was against regulations and he might be de-
moted.
I told him I thought that would be an excellent idea and
left him.
I then encountered a Canadian officer and three sold-
ters who were anxious to get to Kowloon.
We teamed up
and they
forced a sampan to take us over.
got over without difficulty.
There were no Japanese planes visible during our trip.
taxi and went at once to to penna a tea
I was fortunate enough to get a
There I learned
that the Clipper had been destroyed. Also three Condors,
two
DC-2 's and two
of Eurasia's Junkers.
The Clipper crew bad re-
turned to the Peninsula Hotel by that time.
I got back into my
